questions.text: Which of the following is NOT impaired usually in Wilson’s disease?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cognition Patients have difficulty focusing on tasks, but cognition usually is not grossly impaired.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A: Present Option: B: Memory loss, migraine-type headaches, and seizures may occur. Option: C: Autonomic disturbances may include orthostatic hypotension, sweating abnormalities, and bowel, bladder, and sexual dysfunction.

Extraedge:

CNS manifestations in Wilson's disease Dysarthria. Patients have normal intellect. Rigidity like Parkinson's disease and Mask like facies (deposition of copper in basal ganglion). Wing beating tremor dystonia-Risus sardonicus Autonomic symptoms and peripheral neuropathy may be Rarely seen. Main Diagnostic Features of Wilson's Disease CLINICAL SIGNS/SYMPTOMS BIOCHEMICAL/ LABORATORY FINDINGS MOLECULAR FINDINGS Hepatic: Jaundice Anorexia Vomiting Ascites and/or edema. Splenomegaly Neurologic: Dysarthria Facial grimace (risus sardonicus) Drooling Dysphagia Dysgraphia Dystonia Tremor ("wing beating") Ataxial Seizures (rare) Ocular: Kayser-Fleischer ring Sunflower cataract (rare) Psychiatric: Decline in school Personality change Mood disorder Schizophrenia Low serum copper Low serum ceruloplasmin Increased urinary copper excretion Elevated liver enzymes Hypoalbuminemia Increased liver copper level Fatty liver Cirrhotic liver Hemolytic anemial Renal Fanconi syndrome Variants in ATP7B on both chromosomes Variants or polymorphisms in other genes (CAT, SOD2, MTHFR) may influence clinical expression of Wilson's disease in some individuals

questions.correct_answer: D. Kayser-Fleischer ring in Wilson’s disease
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Kayser-Fleischer ring in Wilson’s disease A Kayser-Fleischer ring . Although in this case, the brownish ring Rimming the cornea is visible to the naked eye; slit-lamp examination usually makes confirmation .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A, B: KF ring is seen NOT Cataract in the Option: C: KF ring is seen in Wilson’s disease figure. .

Extraedge:

Kayser Fleischer ring–Copper gets deposited in Descemet's layer. It is seen in almost all(>99% )cases of Neurological wilsons and 30-50% of Hepatic Wilson's disease. KF rings are almost always bilateral. The disappearance of the KF ring occurs with adequate chelation but will take years of treatment to disappear. Sunflower cataract is also seen.

questions.text: Which is the gold standard for diagnosis of Wilson’s disease?

options.label: C
options.text: Liver biopsy with quantitative copper essay

questions.correct_answer: C. Liver biopsy with quantitative copper essay
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Liver biopsy with quantitative copper essay The gold standard for diagnosis remains liver biopsy with quantitative copper assays .

Highyeild:

The gold standard to diagnose wilsons is BIOPSY with a copper concentration in the liver, measured by Neutron Activation Analysis/Atomic absorption spectrometry. Gross vacuolisation and fatty changes are seen. Electron microscopy- Tennis racket appearance.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A: Urine copper measurement is an essential diagnostic tool. Symptomatic patients invariably have urine copper levels >1.6 μmol (>100 μg) per 24 hrs. Option: B: Copper stains are not reliable. False-positive results can occur with long-standing obstructive liver disease, which can elevate hepatic and urine copper concentrations and rarely causes Kayser-Fleischer rings. Option: D: Testing for mutations in ATP7B can be done and is recommended for a definitive diagnosis.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with Wilson’s disease. Which of the following features is true about its progression?

options.label: A
options.text: Non ceruloplasmin serum copper levels increase, resulting in copper clearance in other parts of the body

options.label: B
options.text: Non ceruloplasmin serum copper levels decrease, resulting in copper clearance in other parts of the body

options.label: C
options.text: Non ceruloplasmin serum copper levels increase, resulting in copper build up in other parts of the body

options.label: D
options.text: Non ceruloplasmin serum copper levels decrease, resulting in copper build up in other parts of the body

questions.correct_answer: C. Non ceruloplasmin serum copper levels increase, resulting in copper build up in other parts of the body
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Non ceruloplasmin serum copper levels increase, resulting in copper build up in other parts of the body Defective copper incorporation into apo ceruloplasmin leads to excess catabolism and low blood levels of ceruloplasmin. Serum copper levels are usually lower than normal because of low blood levels of ceruloplasmin, which normally binds >90% of serum copper. As the disease progresses, non ceruloplasmin serum copper (‘free’ copper) levels increase, resulting in copper build up in other parts of the body (e.g., in the brain, with consequent neurologic and psychiatric disease).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A: Copper build-up occurs with progression NOT clearance. Option: B, D: As the disease progresses , non ceruloplasmin serum copper (‘free’ copper) levels increase.

Extraedge:

Mutation of ATP7b Gene on Chromosome 13q- Wilson's disease. Mutation on ATP 7a Gene- Menkes kinky hair syndrome. Copper Bound to apoceruloplasmin– Holo Ceruloplasmin –Mutation of ATP gene causes impairment of biliary copper excretion and copper is not incorporated to ceruloplasmin.---ceruloplasmin is degraded quickly– serum ceruloplasmin levels are low.

questions.text: A 19 year male is diagnosed with Wilson’s disease. He shows Liver cirrhosis but no evidence of hepatic decompensation or psychiatric symptoms. Which is therapy of choice in the patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Zinc For patients with hepatitis or cirrhosis but without evidence of hepatic decompensation or neurologic/psychiatric symptoms, zinc is the therapy of choice although some experts advocate therapy with trientine. It produces a negative copper balance by blocking intestinal absorption of copper , and it induces hepatic metallothionein synthesis, thereby sequestering additional toxic copper.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A: Penicillamine was previously the primary anti copper treatment but now plays only a minor role because of its toxicity and because it often worsens existing neurologic disease if used as initial therapy. If penicillamine is given, it should always be accompanied by pyridoxine (25 mg/d). Option: B: Trientine is a less toxic chelator and is supplanting penicillamine when a chelator is indicated. Option: D: For initial neurologic therapy, tetrathiomolybdate is emerging as the drug of choice because of its rapid control of free copper, preservation of neurologic function, and low toxicity.

questions.text: A 21 year female with Wilson’s disease shows moderate hepatic decompensation. Which is the appropriate treatment?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Trientine and zinc Option: A: Hepatitis or cirrhosis without decompensation. Option: B: Trientine is usually a second choice when used alone. Option: D: Second line for mild hepatic decompensation. questions.text: A 12 year male is diagnosed with Wilson’s disease. Lab investigation shows: Serum bilirubin 10 mg/dL, AST 180 IU/L and Prolongation of PT 6s. What is the Total Score in Prognostic Index of Nazer of the patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

5 We add all 3 values Prognostic index of Nazer is used in wilsons disease. The three components are serum bilirubin serum aspartate amino transferase prothrombin time Here score is: 2(bilirubin) +2(AST) +1 (PT prolong)= 5. Option: A, C, D: Incorrect choices. questions.text: A 16 year female with Wilson’s disease shows lab parameters as: Serum bilirubin 19 mg/dL, AST 260 IU/L and Prolongation of PT 15s. What is the appropriate management based on patient status?

options.label: C
options.text: Medical therapy with Zinc and trientine

options.label: D
options.text: Needs clinical judgement for deciding line of therapy

questions.correct_answer: A. Consider immediately for liver transplantation
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Consider immediately for liver transplantation Here score is: 4(bilirubin) +3(AST) + 3(PT prolong)= 10 . Patients with scores < 7 can usually be managed with medical therapy. Patients with scores >9 should be considered immediately for liver transplantation.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B: Hepatitis or cirrhosis without decompensation. Option: C: A combination of trientine and zinc has been used to treat patients with Nazer scores as high as 9 , but such patients should be watched carefully for indications of hepatic deterioration, which mandates transplantation. Option: D: For patients with scores between 7 and 9, clinical judgment is required in deciding whether to recommend transplantation or medical therapy.
